title: Quiz 1: Health Promotion and Human Nutrition
description: Diploma in Community Health Nursing - Year 1 Semester 2

questions.question: A Community Health Nurse educator has a responsibility to:

options.text: Manipulating the behavior of the Community members
Disseminating information about the Prevention of Diseases and promotion of Health
Determine the proper focus for Health Promotion

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Disseminating information about the Prevention of Diseases and promotion of Health Explanation: The primary role of a nurse educator in health promotion is to share accurate, evidence-based information to empower the community to make healthy choices, rather than manipulating or propagandizing.

questions.question: In Community Strategy, the health services at level one is directed to:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Households and Villages Explanation: In the Kenya Essential Package for Health (KEPH), Level 1 services are delivered at the community level (villages/households) by Community Health Volunteers/Promoters.

questions.question: The following is the Primary goal of Health Promotion;

options.text: Early diagnosis and treat of illnesses
Focus solely on individual behavior change
Empower Individuals and Community to optimize health status
Provide rehabilitation services to the impaired persons

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Empower Individuals and Community to optimize health status Explanation: Health promotion is defined as the process of enabling people to increase control over, and to improve, their health (Ottawa Charter).

questions.question: The following is an example of a community-based health promotion strategy;

options.text: Prescribing medication to a patient with high blood pressure
Preparing a community garden with access to fresh produce
Recommending a specific fitness app to a client
Performing a surgery to remove a malignant tumor

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Preparing a community garden with access to fresh produce Explanation: A community garden creates a supportive environment for nutrition, addressing health at a population/structural level rather than an individual clinical level.

questions.question: Approach to health promotion that focuses on changing social and environmental factors that influence health behaviors;
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Community development approach Explanation: The community development approach aims to address the socio-economic and environmental determinants of health through collective action, rather than focusing solely on individual behavior.

questions.question: When developing a health promotion material, it's important to consider:

options.text: Focus solely on the negative health practices in the community
Present information in a single language only
Tailoring the message to the target audience

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Tailoring the message to the target audience Explanation: Effective IEC materials must be culturally appropriate, readable, and relevant to the specific needs and literacy levels of the audience.

questions.question: The following is an example of primary prevention strategy in health promotion;

options.text: Encouraging healthy eating habits to maintain normal Body Mass Index
Early detection of breast cancer through screenings
Provide medication to lower High blood pressure

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. Encouraging healthy eating habits to maintain normal Body Mass Index Explanation: Primary prevention aims to prevent disease before it occurs (e.g., diet). Screening (B) is Secondary prevention. Treatment (C/D) is Tertiary prevention.

questions.question: The Ottawa Charter for Health emphasizes the importance of creating supportive environments for health. The following is an example of creating a supportive environment;

options.text: Creating designated areas for smoking in public places
Fast food advertising aimed at the malnourished children
Encouraging the community to utilize available resources to improve their health

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Accessible parks and recreational facilities Explanation: Creating supportive environments involves making the healthy choice the easy choice. Parks facilitate physical activity. (Note: Creating smoking areas creates an environment for smoking, not health, though it protects non-smokers; parks are a more direct positive example).

questions.question: Health Education approach that focuses on addressing the underlying social, economic and environmental factors that influence health;
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Empowerment approach Explanation: The empowerment (or social change) approach seeks to help people understand and change the social/environmental causes of ill health.

questions.question: A health message that is perceived to be trustworthy by the receiver is described as
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Credible Explanation: Credibility refers to the trustworthiness and expertise of the source as perceived by the receiver.

questions.question: Explain five key areas identified in the Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion. (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: Building Healthy Public Policy: Putting health on the agenda of policy makers in all sectors (e.g., taxation, legislation). Creating Supportive Environments: Making living and working conditions safe, stimulating, and enjoyable (e.g., green spaces). Strengthening Community Actions: Empowering communities to control their own endeavors and destinies (e.g., self-help groups). Developing Personal Skills: Providing information and education for health to enhance life skills (e.g., health literacy). Reorienting Health Services: Moving beyond clinical/curative services to a focus on health promotion and prevention.

questions.question: Outline five objectives of Health Education. (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: To encourage people to adopt and sustain health-promoting lifestyles and practices. To promote the proper use of health services available to the community. To provide new knowledge and improve skills for making rational health decisions. To arouse interest and change attitudes regarding health matters. To stimulate individual and community self-reliance and participation in health development.

questions.question: Outline the five steps of community mobilization. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Entry into the Community: Establishing rapport with leaders and understanding community structures. Community Assessment/Diagnosis: Identifying needs, resources, and problems with the community. Planning: Developing an action plan with objectives and strategies together with the community. Implementation: Carrying out the planned activities utilizing community resources. Monitoring and Evaluation: Assessing progress and impact, then replanning.

questions.question: State five benefits of community dialogue. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Ownership: Promotes a sense of ownership of health problems and solutions by the community. Resource Mobilization: Helps identify and utilize local resources efficiently. Consensus Building: Helps resolve conflicts and reach agreements on priorities. Empowerment: Gives community members a voice and confidence to act. Sustainability: Solutions developed through dialogue are more likely to be culturally acceptable and sustainable.

questions.question: You are a practicing Community Health Nurse at Migosi Health Centre. In collaboration with the community leaders, a community dialogue has been scheduled to address the health challenges affecting the community. Discuss five principles of an Organized Community Dialogue and explain the Steps to be followed in conducting an Organized Community Dialogue. (20 Marks)
questions.explanation: Part A: Principles of Organized Community Dialogue (10 Marks) Inclusivity: Ensure representation from all segments of the community (women, youth, elderly, marginalized groups) so diverse views are heard. Respect: Participants must respect each other's opinions and culture. The facilitator should ensure a safe, non-judgmental environment. Transparency: The purpose, process, and outcomes of the dialogue should be clear to all. No hidden agendas. Participation: Active engagement of all members should be encouraged. It should not be dominated by leaders or experts. Relevance: The dialogue must address issues that are felt needs of the community and are timely. Part B: Steps in Conducting Organized Community Dialogue (10 Marks) Preparation (Pre-dialogue): Define the specific topic/issue. Identify key stakeholders and mobilize participants. Select a suitable venue (neutral, accessible) and time. Prepare materials (flip charts, markers). Introduction/Climate Setting: Welcome participants and introduce facilitators/leaders. Explain objectives and set ground rules (e.g., one person speaks at a time). Create a relaxed atmosphere (ice breakers). Problem Identification & Analysis: Facilitate discussion to define the problem clearly. Explore root causes (Why is this happening?) and effects. Use tools like problem trees or mapping. Action Planning (Way Forward): Brainstorm solutions. Agree on specific actions: What will be done? By whom? By when? With what resources? Form a committee if necessary. Closing and Evaluation: Summarize key decisions. Agree on a date for the next meeting/follow-up. Thank participants and close.

questions.question: During growth monitoring of a child, Failure to thrive is diagnosed when.

options.text: A child presents with severe wasting.
The Weight is below 60% of normal weight.
The child present s with old man's face.
Weight is 80% of the normal weight.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. The Weight is below 60% of normal weight. Explanation: While definitions vary (often simply stagnant growth curve), in the context of Gomez classification used in older curricula, severe malnutrition (often linked to Marasmus/FTT clinical picture) is weight <60% of expected.

questions.question: The best practice during weaning process is

options.text: Variety of food may be introduced at ago.
Cultural beliefs of the family must be considered.
Breast milk must be given prior to new food.
Avoid introducing variety of food at ago.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Avoid introducing variety of food at ago. Explanation: New foods should be introduced one at a time to identify any allergies or intolerances.

questions.question: While giving advice on macronutrients, first class proteins include.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. Meat and milk. Explanation: First class proteins (High Biological Value) contain all essential amino acids and are typically of animal origin (meat, milk, eggs, fish).

questions.question: Insufficient calcium in the body may lead to the following conditions;
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Bone demineralization. Explanation: Calcium deficiency leads to resorption of calcium from bones (osteomalacia, rickets, osteoporosis) to maintain blood levels.

questions.question: Macronutrients are required in large quantity and Includes
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. Proteins and carbohydrates. Explanation: Macronutrients are Proteins, Fats, and Carbohydrates. Vitamins and Minerals are Micronutrients.

questions.question: Indicate whether the following statements are TRUE or FALSE
Match the nutritional disorders in column A with their correct deficiencies in column B
questions.explanation: (a) Osteomalacia → Vitamin D (and Calcium) (b) Xerophthalmia → Vitamin A (c) Pellagra → Niacin (Vitamin B3) (d) Scurvy → Vitamin C

questions.question: The appropriate therapeutic diet for patients on tube feeds is;

options.text: High calorie, high protein, potassium controlled
High protein, high fat, low carbohydrate
High protein, high carbohydrate, fat controlled

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C. High protein, high carbohydrate, fat controlled Explanation: Tube feeding formulas are generally balanced but often favor high protein for healing/maintenance and controlled fat for digestibility, unless specific disease states (like renal failure, option D) dictate otherwise. C is the best general description.

questions.question: A Body Mass Index(BMI) of 25 is classified as
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Overweight Explanation: BMI Categories: <18.5 (Underweight), 18.5-24.9 (Normal), 25.0-29.9 (Overweight), ≥30 (Obese). A BMI of exactly 25 falls into the start of the Overweight category.

questions.question: The best source of calcium is
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D. Milk Explanation: Dairy products (milk, cheese, yogurt) are the richest and most bioavailable sources of calcium.

questions.question: Explain three (3) methods used in nutritional status assessment. (6 marks)
questions.explanation: Anthropometry: Measuring physical dimensions (weight, height, MUAC) to compare against standards (BMI, Z-scores). Biochemical Assessment: Analyzing body fluids (blood, urine) for nutrient levels (e.g., Hemoglobin for iron, Albumin for protein). Clinical Assessment: Physical examination for signs of deficiency (e.g., pallor, edema, hair changes). Dietary Assessment: Asking about food intake (24hr recall, food frequency) to estimate nutrient consumption.

questions.question: State four functions of protein. (4 marks)
questions.explanation: Body building and repair of tissues (growth). Production of enzymes and hormones. Production of antibodies (immune function). Source of energy (secondary function). Maintenance of fluid balance (oncotic pressure via albumin).

questions.question: State five (5) roles of a community health nurse in ensuring good nutrition in the community. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Nutritional Education: Teaching families about balanced diets and breastfeeding. Growth Monitoring: Regular weighing of children to detect malnutrition early. Supplementation: Distributing Vitamin A, Iron/Folate to vulnerable groups. Assessment: Screening for malnutrition signs in the community. Advocacy: Promoting food security initiatives like kitchen gardens.

questions.question: Outline five (5) factors to consider when feeding the elderly. (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Reduced BMR: Lower calorie needs but high nutrient density required. Dental Issues: Texture may need modification (soft/minced) due to poor teeth/dentures. Reduced Taste/Smell: Food should be flavorful to stimulate appetite. Digestion: Reduced gastric acid/motility requires smaller, frequent meals and fiber for constipation. Mobility/Dexterity: May need assistance or adaptive utensils to eat. Hydration: Thirst mechanism is blunted; need deliberate fluid intake.

questions.question: Master P, 2 years old, presents in the hospital with severe wasting and Oedema of both lower limbs among other signs and symptoms of severe Protein Energy Malnutrition. He is for admission. Explain the four factors predisposing to Protein Energy Malnutrition and discuss the management of Master P till discharge. (20 marks)
questions.explanation: A. Factors Predisposing to PEM (4 Marks): Inadequate Dietary Intake: Early weaning, diluted formula, or lack of food due to poverty (food insecurity). Infections: Recurrent illnesses (diarrhea, measles, respiratory infections) increase nutrient needs while decreasing appetite. Maternal Factors: Lack of breastfeeding, poor maternal nutrition, ignorance/lack of knowledge on proper feeding practices. Socio-economic Factors: Poverty, large family size, displacement/conflict preventing access to food. B. Management of Master P (Marasmic-Kwashiorkor) (16 Marks): The management follows the WHO 10 Steps for Severe Acute Malnutrition: Phase 1: Stabilization (Days 1-7) Hypoglycemia: Treat/prevent with 10% dextrose or F-75 feed immediately. Feed every 2-3 hours. Hypothermia: Keep warm (Kangaroo care), cover head, keep room warm. No bathing initially. Dehydration: Use ReSoMal (special rehydration solution low in sodium, high in potassium). Do not use standard ORS). Electrolytes: Correct imbalance (Potassium and Magnesium supplementation is crucial). Infection: Treat with broad-spectrum antibiotics (routine) and measles vaccine if due. Micronutrients: Give Vitamin A, Folic acid, Zinc, Copper. (Withhold Iron until rehabilitation phase). Cautious Feeding: Start F-75 formula (low protein/sodium) to prevent refeeding syndrome. Small frequent feeds. Phase 2: Rehabilitation (Weeks 2-6) Rebuild Wasted Tissues: Transition to F-100 or RUTF (Ready-to-Use Therapeutic Food). Increase calorie and protein intake to support rapid weight gain. Introduce Iron. Stimulation: Provide tender loving care, play therapy, and a stimulating environment. Prepare for Follow-up: Educate parents on proper nutrition and hygiene. Discharge when weight gain is achieved, edema lost, and clinically well.
